sen.j: 田辺城（たなべじょう）は京都府舞鶴市にある戦国時代から江戸時代にかけての城。
sen.e: Tanabe-jo Castle, located in Maizuru City, Koto Prefecture, was build between Sengoku Period and Edo Period.
Tanabe-jo Castle, located in Maizuru City, Koto Prefecture, was build between Sengoku Period and Edo Period.
Tanabe-jo Castle, located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture, was build between Sengoku Period and Edo Period.

sen.j: 別名は舞鶴城（まいづるじょう）。
sen.e: It is also known as Maizuru-jo Castle.

sen.j: 1578年（天正6年）織田信長の命によって守護大名の一色義道を滅ぼし、丹後国を制圧した細川幽斎（幽斎）がこの地を与えられ、はじめは宮津城を居城としたが、畿内に近く交通の要所であった加佐郡田辺の地に、田辺城を築き、丹後経営の中心とした。
sen.e: In1578, Fujitaka HOSOKAW, ordered by Nobunaga ODA, conquered Tango-no Kuni by destroying Shugo Daimyo, Yoshimichi ISSHIKI, and being allowed to control the area, Fujitaka first settled in Miyazu-jo Castle, and later built Tanabe-jo Castle in Tanabe, Kasa Gun, which was strategically important for transportation and close to Kinai as well, to make it the center of governing the area of Tango no Kuni.
sen.cmt: 後で（セルB18）同一人として，説明なくいきなり藤孝の記述があるので，この項で藤孝に変更しました．細川藤孝（幽斎）→Fujitaka (Yusai) HOSOKAWA[http://sankei.jp.msn.com/life/trend/081122/trd0811221703015-n1.htm]畿内→[定訳不明]Kinai
sen.e: In 1578, Fujitaka HOSOKAW, as instructed by Nobunaga ODA, conquered Tango-no Kuni by destroying Shugo Daimyo Yoshimichi ISSHIKI; thus being allowed to control the area, Fujitaka first settled in Miyazu-jo Castle but later built Tanabe-jo Castle in Tanabe, Kasa Gun, which was strategically important for transportation and close to Kinai, in order to make it the center for governing the area of Tango no Kuni.

In 1578, Fujitaka HOSOKAWA, as instructed by Nobunaga ODA, conquered Tango Province by destroying Shugo Daimyo (Guardian Feudal Lord) Yoshimichi ISSHIKI; thus being allowed to control the area, Fujitaka first settled in Miyazu-jo Castle but later built Tanabe-jo Castle in Tanabe, Kasa Gun, which was strategically important for transportation and close to Kinai, in order to make it the center for governing the area of Tango Province.
sen.cmt: 人名のスペル修正、(Guardian Feudal Lord)の追加"Tango-no Kuni"→"Tango Province"に変更しました。

sen.j: 隠居後は、子の細川忠興を入城させた。
sen.e: His son, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA inherited the castle when Fujitaka retired.
His son, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, inherited the castle when Fujitaka retired.

sen.j: 1600年（慶長5年）関ヶ原の戦いが勃発すると、当主になっていた細川忠興は石田三成率いる西軍の誘いを退け、徳川家康率いる東軍に加勢した。
sen.e: In 1600, when the Battle of Sekigahara broke out, as a head of Hosokawa clan, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA declined the invitation of Sei-Gun lead by Mitsunari ISHIDA to join them, and his army sided with To-Gun headed by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

In 1600, when the Battle of Sekigahara broke out, as the head of the Hosokawa clan, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA declined the invitation of Sei-Gun (led by Mitsunari ISHIDA) to join them, and instead his army sided with To-Gun, which was headed by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

In 1600, when the Battle of Sekigahara broke out, as the head of the Hosokawa clan, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA declined the invitation of Sei-Gun (western camp, led by Mitsunari ISHIDA) to join them, and instead his army sided with To-Gun (eastern camp), which was headed by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 隠居していた藤孝は自分の居城である宮津城では西軍の攻勢を防げないと考え、宮津城を焼き払い、田辺城に入城、雲霞のごとく取り囲む西軍を迎え撃った。
sen.e: Fujitaka, who had been retired then at Miyazu-jo Castle, judging the castle was too fragile to defend against Sei-Gun attack, set fire on it, and his army entered Tanabe-jo Castle to counter the armies of Sei-Gun which were advancing to encircle the castle like a fog.

Fujitaka had retired at Miyazu-jo Castle but now judged that the castle was too fragile to defend against a Sei-Gun attack and therefore set it ablaze, and his army entered Tanabe-jo Castle to counter the armies of Sei-Gun, which were advancing like a fog to encircle the castle.

Fujitaka had retired at Miyazu-jo Castle but now judged that the castle was too fragile to defend against a Sei-Gun attack and therefore set it ablaze, and his army entered Tanabe-jo Castle to counter the armies of Sei-Gun, which were advancing like a fog to encircle the castle.

sen.j: 田辺城はすぐさま、石田三成の家老島清興の親族にあたる小野木重勝や豊臣家の重臣前田玄以の子前田茂勝が率いる西軍・1万5千人もの大軍で包囲されると、50日にも及ぶ長期戦となった。
sen.e: The battle continued for as long as 50 days after Tanabe-jo Castle was quickly besieged by a large force of 15 thousand soldiers of Sei-Gun, whose leaders included Shigekatsu ONOGI who was a relative of Kiyoki SHIMA, Mitsunari ISHIDA's chief retainer, and Shigekatsu MAEDA who was the son of Geni MAEDA, an important retainer of Toyotomi clan.

The battle continued for as long as 50 days after Tanabe-jo Castle was quickly besieged by a force of 15,000 soldiers of Sei-Gun, whose leaders included Shigekatsu ONOGI, a relative of Kiyoki SHIMA, Mitsunari ISHIDA's chief retainer, and Shigekatsu MAEDA, who was the son of Geni MAEDA, an important retainer of the Toyotomi family.

sen.j: 激闘の末、弾薬が尽きた藤孝は自身のもつ「古今伝授の書」が戦火で忘却されるのを恐れ、それを後陽成天皇に献上した。
sen.e: Fujitaka, running out of ammunition after a fierce battle, worried that his "Kokindenjyu no Sho"might be damaged and lost in the war, and offered it to Emperor Go-Yozei.
Fujitaka, running out of ammunition after a fierce battle, worried that his "Kokindenjyu no Sho" might be damaged and lost in the war, so he offered it to Emperor Go-Yozei.
Fujitaka, running out of ammunition after a fierce battle, worried that his "Kokindenju no Sho" might be damaged and lost in the war, so he offered it to Emperor Goyozei.
sen.cmt: 人名のスペル修正"Kokindenjyu"→"Kokindenju"に変更しました。

sen.j: 藤孝の戦死を憂いた後陽成天皇の仲介で西軍は攻撃をするのをやめ、命を助けられた。
sen.e: Fujitaka survived because Sei-Gun eventually stopped its attack thanks to intervention of Emperor Go-Yozei who worried about Fujitaka's imminent death in the battle.
Fujitaka survived because Sei-Gun eventually stopped its attack thanks to the intervention of Emperor Go-Yozei, who worried about Fujitaka's imminent death in the battle.
Fujitaka survived because Sei-Gun eventually stopped its attack thanks to the intervention of Emperor Goyozei, who worried about Fujitaka's imminent death in the battle.

sen.j: 田辺城を開城した藤孝は敵将前田茂勝の丹波亀山城に入った。
sen.e: Fujitaka surrendered Tanabe-jo Castle, and settled in Tanba-Kameyama-jo Castle in Tanba, which was owned by the enemy general, Shigekatsu MAEDA
Fujitaka surrendered Tanabe-jo Castle and instead settled in Tanba-Kameyama-jo Castle in Tanba, which was owned by the enemy general, Shigekatsu MAEDA.

sen.j: こののち細川忠興は九州小倉に転封され、京極高知が丹後一国12万3千石を与えられ仮に田辺城に入城したが、宮津城を再築し宮津城へ本拠地を移した。
sen.e: After this, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA was transferred to Kokura, Kyushu, and Takatomo KYOGOKU temporarily entered Tanabe-jo Castle with 123 thousand koku to govern Tango no Kuni, but later he rebuilt Miyazu-jo Castle to be based there.

After this, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA was transferred to Kokura, in Kyushu, and Takatomo KYOGOKU temporarily entered Tanabe-jo Castle with 123,000 koku to govern Tango no Kuni, but later he rebuilt Miyazu-jo Castle in order to establish a base there.

sen.j: このとき田辺城の建造物は、ことごとく破壊されたと伝えられている（一国一城令）。
sen.e: On this occasion, all the buildings of Tanabe-jo Castle were reportedly destroyed (Ikkoku Ichijyo Rei).
Reportedly, on this occasion all the buildings of Tanabe-jo Castle were destroyed (Ikkoku Ichijyo Rei).

sen.j: 京極高知の遺言によって京極家は嫡男・高広が宮津藩7万5千石、次男・高三が丹後田辺藩（舞鶴藩）3万5千石、養子・高信が峰山藩1万3千石を相続した。
sen.e: According to Takatomo KYOGOKU's will, among Kyogoku family members, his eldest son, Takahiro inherited Miyazu han with 70 thousand koku, the second son, Takamitsu, Tanngo-Tanabe han (Maizuru han) with 35 thousand koku, and the adopted son, Takanobu, Mineyama han with 13 thousand koku.

According to Takatomo KYOGOKU's will, among the Kyogoku family members his eldest son Takahiro inherited the Miyazu han with 70,000 koku, the second son Takamitsu inherited the Tanngo-Tanabe han (Maizuru han) with 35,000 koku, and the adopted son Takanobu inherited the Mineyama han with 13,000 koku.

According to Takatomo KYOGOKU's will, among the Kyogoku family members his eldest son Takahiro inherited the Miyazu domain with 70,000 koku, the second son Takamitsu inherited the Tango-Tanabe domain (Maizuru domain) with 35,000 koku, and the adopted son Takanobu inherited the Mineyama domain with 13,000 koku.

sen.j: 初代舞鶴藩主となった京極高三により石垣の修復や櫓の再建が図られ、荒廃していた田辺城は再興された。
sen.e: Takamitsu KYOGOKU, the first lord of Maizuru han, reconstructed Tanabe-jo Castle from the devastation, renovating its stonewalling and rebuilding the turrets.
Takamitsu KYOGOKU, the first lord of the Maizuru han, reconstructed Tanabe-jo Castle from the devastation, renovating its stone walls and rebuilding the turrets.
Takamitsu KYOGOKU, the first lord of the Maizuru domain, reconstructed Tanabe-jo Castle from the devastation, renovating its stone walls and rebuilding the watchtowers.
sen.cmt: hanをdomainに修正。Turrets（動楼）をwatchtowers（監視塔）に変更。

sen.j: 京極氏は3代続いた後、豊岡藩へ転封となり、代わって牧野氏が1668年（寛文8年）3万5千石で入封すると、田辺城の大手門その他の城門・石垣などが改築され、それを代々世襲し明治の時代まで繁栄した。
sen.e: Kyogoku clan, being transferred to Toyooka han after three generations, was replaced by Makino clan with 35 thousand koku in 1668, the clan rebuilt the Main Gate, other gates, and stone walls of Tanabe-jo Castle, and continued the engineering work and its prosperity by heredity for generations until Meiji era.

The Kyogoku clan, having been transferred to the Toyooka han after three generations, was in 1668 replaced by the Makino clan with 35,000 koku; the clan rebuilt the main gate, other gates and stone walls of Tanabe-jo Castle, and as part of its heritage continued the engineering work and prosperity for generations till the Meiji era.

The Kyogoku clan, having been transferred to the Toyooka domain after three generations, was in 1668 replaced by the Makino clan with 35,000 koku; the clan rebuilt the main gate, other gates and stone walls of Tanabe-jo Castle, and as part of its heritage continued the engineering work and prosperity for generations till the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: hanをdomainに、Meiji eraをMeiji periodに修正。

sen.j: 現在、田辺城跡は公園になっており、1940年（昭和15年）に復興された二層櫓の彰古館、1997年(平成4年)に復興された城門には田辺城資料館、天守台石塁などがある。
sen.e: Today, the compound of Tanabe-jo Castle is a garden with Shouko Kan of two-level tower which was rebuilt in 1940, Tanabe-jo Castle Museum in the castle gate rebuilt in 1997, and the stone mound foundation for tenshu.

The compound of Tanabe-jo Castle is now a garden surrounding the Shouko Kan (two-level tower), which was rebuilt in 1940, Tanabe-jo Castle Museum in the castle gate (rebuilt in 1997) and the stone mound foundation for tenshu.

The compound of former Tanabe-jo Castle is now a garden surrounding the Shouko Kan (two-level tower), which was rebuilt in 1940, Tanabe-jo Castle Museum in the castle gate (rebuilt in 1997) and the stone mound foundation for tenshu (main keep).
